body.p:
March 7' 1861
To his Excellency Governor Magoffin

Your Petitioner Michael B. Johnson states that he is a citizen and resident of Lexington Ky and was a citizen and resident of this place in Sept. 1859; about which time he, with a view to make something with which to support his family, rented the booths on the Fair Grounds at Crab Orchard Ky; and during the Fair he opened these booths and endeavored to the best of his ability to have his business there conducted in an orderly manner. During the Session of the Lincoln Circuit Court, held shortly after said Fair, he was indicted in some four cases for selling liquor by the drink. Your Petitioner believed that if he attended Court and defended these cases, that he would get clear of them; but knowing that he could not attend and take his witnesses ^who lived in Lex;^ without considerable expense to him; he agreed to compromise the same by letting judgment go against him in two of the cases; all others to be dismissed. So judgment was entered against him for $20 -- in each case and this your Petitioner intended, and promised in good faith, to pay. An execution for the same was sent to this county but your Petitioner was unable to pay it and having no property out which it could be made, it was returned "no property."

A Capias has been issued and is now in the hands of the Shff. of this County. Your Petitioner now state he is totally unable to pay the same. He representes to you that he has recently been unfortunate and been broken up in his business and that he has a family dependant upon him; and that unless the ^execution of the^ process, now in the hands of the Shff. is arrested by your order, it will be a source of real distress to him.
He therefore respectfully asks you to remit said fines.
Sworn to before me this 6th day of March 1861,
C D Carr P J F Co

Lincoln Circuit
M B Johnson
Two judgments $20
Isd
Respite 12 mos
